content.description: Introduction to Hangul writing system with basic vowels (ㅏ, ㅓ, ㅗ, ㅜ, ㅡ, ㅣ) and consonants (ㄱ, ㄴ, ㄷ, ㄹ, ㅁ, ㅂ, ㅅ)

descriptionTranslations.de: Einführung in das Hangul-Schriftsystem mit grundlegenden Vokalen (ㅏ, ㅓ, ㅗ, ㅜ, ㅡ, ㅣ) und Konsonanten (ㄱ, ㄴ, ㄷ, ㄹ, ㅁ, ㅂ, ㅅ)

vocabulary.meaning: Basic vowel sound 'ah' as in 'father'. Fundamental vowel used in many Korean words and syllables. Represented by a vertical line with a horizontal stroke to the right.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always used as part of syllable blocks, never written alone in words

vocabulary.meaning: Basic vowel sound 'uh' as in 'but'. Complementary vowel to ㅏ, distinguished by the horizontal stroke appearing on the left side of the vertical line.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often confused with ㅏ by beginners, but has distinctly different pronunciation

vocabulary.meaning: Basic vowel sound 'oh' as in 'boat'. Represented by a horizontal line with a vertical stroke pointing upward, indicating the mouth position for this sound.
vocabulary.usageNote: Forms the foundation for compound vowels like ㅘ and ㅙ

vocabulary.meaning: Basic vowel sound 'oo' as in 'moon'. Complementary to ㅗ, with the vertical stroke pointing downward to indicate the different mouth position.
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential for many common Korean words and grammatical endings

vocabulary.meaning: Neutral vowel sound similar to 'uh' but with lips more relaxed. Unique to Korean and often challenging for beginners. Represented by a simple horizontal line.
vocabulary.usageNote: Appears frequently in Korean words and has no direct English equivalent

vocabulary.meaning: Basic vowel sound 'ee' as in 'see'. Simplest vowel in Hangul, represented by a single vertical line. Used in many grammatical particles and endings.
vocabulary.usageNote: Most common vowel in Korean, essential for sentence particles

vocabulary.meaning: Basic consonant with sounds ranging from 'g' to 'k' depending on position in syllable. Fundamental consonant shaped like the corner of a square, representing the tongue position.
vocabulary.usageNote: Voiced 'g' sound between vowels, unvoiced 'k' sound at syllable start

vocabulary.meaning: Consonant representing the 'n' sound. Shape mimics the tongue position against the roof of the mouth when making this sound. Very common in Korean words.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can appear at beginning, middle, or end of syllables

grammar.meaning: Korean writing system organizes letters into square syllable blocks rather than linear sequences. Each block contains 2-4 letters: initial consonant + vowel + optional final consonant(s). This spatial arrangement is fundamental to Korean writing and reading.
grammar.formation: 1) Start with initial consonant (top-left), 2) Add vowel (right side for vertical vowels like ㅣ, bottom for horizontal vowels like ㅗ), 3) Add final consonant if needed (bottom)
grammar.usageNotes: Every syllable must have at least one consonant and one vowel. Silent placeholder ㅇ is used when syllable starts with vowel sound.

content.description: Complex vowels (ㅑ, ㅕ, ㅛ, ㅠ, ㅐ, ㅔ) and remaining basic consonants (ㅇ, ㅈ, ㅊ, ㅋ, ㅌ, ㅍ, ㅎ)

descriptionTranslations.de: Komplexe Vokale (ㅑ, ㅕ, ㅛ, ㅠ, ㅐ, ㅔ) und die verbleibenden grundlegenden Konsonanten (ㅇ, ㅈ, ㅊ, ㅋ, ㅌ, ㅍ, ㅎ)

vocabulary.meaning: Complex vowel sound 'ya' - formed by combining ㅣ (i) + ㅏ (a). Pronounced like 'ya' in 'yarn'. Used to create syllables with a gliding sound.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always appears with a consonant to form syllables

vocabulary.meaning: Complex vowel sound 'yeo' - formed by combining ㅣ (i) + ㅓ (eo). Pronounced like 'yaw' with a softer ending. Creates a diphthong when combined with consonants.
vocabulary.usageNote: Common in many Korean words and names

vocabulary.meaning: Complex vowel sound 'yo' - formed by combining ㅣ (i) + ㅗ (o). Pronounced like 'yo' in 'yoga'. Often appears in polite speech endings and exclamations.
vocabulary.usageNote: Frequently used in polite verb endings

vocabulary.meaning: Complex vowel sound 'yu' - formed by combining ㅣ (i) + ㅜ (u). Pronounced like 'you' in English. Creates a rounded, gliding sound when combined with consonants.
vocabulary.usageNote: Less common than other y-vowels but essential for complete literacy

vocabulary.meaning: Complex vowel sound 'ae' - pronounced like 'a' in 'cat' or 'had'. Historically a diphthong but now pronounced as a monophthong. Essential for many common Korean words.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often confused with ㅔ by beginners - practice distinguishing the sounds

vocabulary.meaning: Complex vowel sound 'e' - pronounced like 'e' in 'bed' or 'ten'. Slightly different from ㅐ in formal pronunciation. Very common in Korean vocabulary and grammar endings.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used in many verb endings and common words

vocabulary.reading: ieung (silent at start, ng at end)
vocabulary.meaning: Consonant that is silent when at the beginning of a syllable but sounds like 'ng' in 'sing' when at the end. Essential placeholder consonant for vowel-only syllables.
vocabulary.usageNote: Every syllable must start with a consonant - ㅇ serves as silent placeholder

vocabulary.meaning: Consonant sound 'j' - pronounced like 'j' in 'jump' or 'joy'. One of the most frequently used consonants in Korean. Creates a soft affricate sound.
vocabulary.usageNote: Very common in Korean words and names

grammar.meaning: Advanced syllable construction using complex vowels and new consonants. Builds on basic syllable formation by introducing y-glide vowels (ㅑ, ㅕ, ㅛ, ㅠ) and e-sound vowels (ㅐ, ㅔ). These create more sophisticated sound combinations and are essential for reading Korean words accurately. The pattern follows the same structure as basic syllables: Consonant + Complex Vowel (+ Optional Final Consonant).
grammar.formation: 1) Start with any consonant (including ㅇ for vowel sounds) 2) Add complex vowel (ㅑ, ㅕ, ㅛ, ㅠ, ㅐ, ㅔ) 3) Optionally add final consonant 4) Examples: 야 (ya), 저 (jeo), 요 (yo)
grammar.usageNotes: Complex vowels maintain their pronunciation regardless of surrounding consonants. The silent ㅇ is crucial for creating syllables that begin with vowel sounds. Practice distinguishing ㅐ and ㅔ sounds.

content.description: Basic greetings and polite expressions with 요 ending

descriptionTranslations.de: Grundlegende Begrüßungen und höfliche Ausdrücke mit der 요-Endung

vocabulary.meaning: A polite, formal greeting meaning 'hello' or 'how are you.' Used when meeting someone for the first time, with people older than you, or in formal situations. This is the most common and safe greeting to use in Korean.
vocabulary.usageNote: Use with strangers, older people, or in formal settings

vocabulary.meaning: An informal greeting meaning 'hi' or 'bye.' Used with friends, people younger than you, or family members. Can be used both when meeting and parting. Much more casual than 안녕하세요.
vocabulary.usageNote: Use only with close friends or people younger than you

vocabulary.meaning: A formal and polite way to say 'thank you.' This is the most respectful form of expressing gratitude in Korean. Use this with strangers, in business settings, with older people, or when you want to show deep appreciation.
vocabulary.usageNote: Most formal way to say thank you

vocabulary.meaning: A polite but less formal way to say 'thank you.' This is warmer and more personal than 감사합니다, but still polite enough for most situations. Good for daily interactions with people you know somewhat.
vocabulary.usageNote: Polite but friendlier than 감사합니다

vocabulary.meaning: A formal apology meaning 'I'm sorry' or 'excuse me.' Used when you've made a mistake, need to get someone's attention politely, or want to apologize formally. Shows respect and humility.
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal apology or excuse me

vocabulary.meaning: Polite way to say 'yes.' Also used to show you're listening or to acknowledge what someone said. This is more formal than 응 and should be used in polite situations or with people you don't know well.
vocabulary.usageNote: Polite yes, or acknowledgment

vocabulary.meaning: Korean vowel making the 'oo' sound as in 'book.' One of the basic vowels in Hangul. Appears in many Korean words and is essential for reading.
vocabulary.usageNote: Basic Hangul vowel

vocabulary.meaning: Korean vowel making the 'uh' sound. This sound doesn't exist in English but is similar to the 'u' in 'put' but with lips unrounded. Essential vowel that appears in many Korean words.
vocabulary.usageNote: Basic Hangul vowel

vocabulary.meaning: Korean vowel making the 'ee' sound as in 'see.' One of the most frequently used vowels in Korean. Forms the base for many other complex vowels.
vocabulary.usageNote: Basic Hangul vowel

grammar.meaning: The 요 ending is added to verbs and adjectives to make speech polite and respectful. This is the standard polite form used in most everyday conversations. It shows respect to the listener without being overly formal. Essential for proper Korean conversation etiquette.
grammar.formation: Add 요 to the stem of verbs and adjectives. For words ending in vowels, simply attach 요. This creates the polite informal speech level, which is appropriate for most social situations.
grammar.usageNotes: Use with people you don't know well, those older than you, or in any situation where you want to be polite. Avoid with very close friends where casual speech is more appropriate.

content.description: Introducing name and nationality using 이에요/예요

descriptionTranslations.de: Name und Nationalität vorstellen mit 이에요/예요

vocabulary.meaning: Name - refers to a person's given name or full name. Used formally and informally in self-introductions and when asking about someone's identity
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential for basic self-introduction conversations

vocabulary.meaning: I/me (humble form) - polite first-person pronoun used when speaking to someone of higher status or in formal situations. Shows respect and humility
vocabulary.usageNote: Use instead of 나 in polite/formal contexts

vocabulary.meaning: Korea/South Korea - the country name used by Koreans to refer to their nation. Literally means 'great country' (한 = great, 국 = country)
vocabulary.usageNote: Used when stating nationality or origin

vocabulary.meaning: Korean person - nationality term combining the country name (한국) with person (사람). Used to identify someone's nationality
vocabulary.usageNote: Standard way to say 'Korean person' in polite conversation

vocabulary.meaning: America/United States - country name meaning 'beautiful country' (미 = beautiful, 국 = country). Standard term for the USA in Korean
vocabulary.usageNote: Common country name for nationality discussions

vocabulary.meaning: Japan - neighboring country name meaning 'sun origin' (일 = sun, 본 = origin/root). Used when discussing nationality or geography
vocabulary.usageNote: Important neighboring country for Korean speakers

vocabulary.meaning: Person/people - basic word for human being. Used in nationality expressions and general references to people
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential word for describing nationality and identity

vocabulary.meaning: Hello/good day - standard polite greeting appropriate for most situations. Shows respect and politeness in formal interactions
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential greeting for polite conversation

vocabulary.meaning: Thank you - formal polite expression of gratitude. Used in respectful situations to show appreciation
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal thanks appropriate for polite introductions

grammar.meaning: Polite form of 'to be' used for identification and description. 이에요 is used after consonants, 예요 after vowels. This is the polite informal way to state facts about identity, nationality, profession, etc. More casual than 입니다 but still respectful.
grammar.formation: Noun + 이에요 (after consonant) / Noun + 예요 (after vowel). Examples: 학생 + 이에요 = 학생이에요 (student), 의사 + 예요 = 의사예요 (doctor)
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for self-introductions. Use when stating name, nationality, job, or describing things politely. This follows the 요 polite ending pattern learned previously.

vocabulary.meaning: Age - refers to how old someone is. Used in formal and informal contexts when discussing someone's age.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always used with the counter 살 when stating specific age

vocabulary.meaning: Age counter - the counter used specifically for counting years of age. Essential for stating how old someone is in Korean.

vocabulary.meaning: Twenty - the native Korean number for 20, used when counting age and other items that use native Korean numbers.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used instead of 열+열 for the number 20 in native Korean counting

vocabulary.meaning: Family - refers to family members collectively. Used when talking about one's family in general terms.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can be used with counters when talking about family size

vocabulary.meaning: Mother - formal/polite term for mother. Used when speaking formally or when introducing family members to others.
vocabulary.usageNote: More formal than 엄마, appropriate for introductions and formal situations

vocabulary.meaning: Father - formal/polite term for father. Used when speaking formally or when introducing family members to others.
vocabulary.usageNote: More formal than 아빠, appropriate for introductions and formal situations

vocabulary.meaning: Name - a person's given name or full name. Essential vocabulary for self-introductions and asking about others.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used in both formal and informal contexts when discussing names

vocabulary.meaning: Hello/Good day - standard polite greeting used in most formal and semi-formal situations.

vocabulary.meaning: Twenty - alternative form of 스무, used in certain grammatical contexts when combined with other words.

grammar.meaning: Age counter pattern - used after native Korean numbers to express someone's age. This is the standard way to state age in Korean and must always be used when giving specific age information. The pattern is: [native Korean number] + 살 + 이에요/예요.
grammar.formation: Native Korean number (하나→한, 둘→두, 셋→세, etc.) + 살 + 이에요/예요. For numbers ending in vowels, use 살이에요. For numbers ending in consonants, use 살이에요.
grammar.usageNotes: Always use native Korean numbers (하나, 둘, 셋...), never Sino-Korean numbers (일, 이, 삼...) when stating age. Common ages: 한 살, 두 살, 세 살, 네 살, 다섯 살, etc.

grammar.meaning: Integration of all previously learned patterns to form a complete self-introduction. This pattern combines greetings, name introduction, nationality, and age into a coherent self-introduction sequence. Essential for formal and informal social interactions.
grammar.formation: 1) 안녕하세요 (greeting) + 2) 저는 [name]이에요/예요 (name) + 3) [nationality] 사람이에요 (nationality) + 4) 저는 [age]살이에요 (age)
grammar.usageNotes: Follow this sequence for formal introductions. Can be abbreviated for informal situations. Always maintain polite speech level with 이에요/예요 endings in formal contexts.

grammar.meaning: To be/not to be - Korean copula verb that connects a subject with a noun or adjective. 이다 is used after words ending in consonants, 이에요/예요 is the polite form. 아니다 is the negative form meaning 'not to be'.

grammar.usageNotes: Often omitted in casual conversation, especially with family terms. More formal than omitting it. Pronunciation can vary between 의, 에, or 이 depending on dialect and speed of speech.

descriptionTranslations.de: Berufe und Beschreibung der beruflichen Tätigkeiten von Familienmitgliedern

vocabulary.meaning: Work or job - refers to any kind of employment or occupation. Used both as a standalone noun meaning 'work' and as part of compound words for specific jobs.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can be used alone (일해요 - work) or combined with other words (회사일 - company work)

vocabulary.meaning: Doctor or physician - a medical professional who diagnoses and treats patients. One of the most respected professions in Korean society.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often preceded by title markers when addressing directly

vocabulary.meaning: Teacher - an educator who works in schools, academies, or provides private tutoring. The honorific suffix -님 shows respect for the teaching profession.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always includes the honorific -님 when referring to teachers

vocabulary.meaning: Company employee or office worker - someone who works for a corporation or business. A very common occupation in modern Korea.
vocabulary.usageNote: Generic term for white-collar workers in companies

vocabulary.meaning: Student - someone who is currently studying at any educational institution from elementary school to university.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can refer to students of any age or level

vocabulary.meaning: Chef or cook - a professional who prepares food in restaurants, hotels, or other establishments. Combines 요리 (cooking) + 사 (person).
vocabulary.usageNote: Professional cooking position, distinct from home cooking

vocabulary.meaning: Nurse - a healthcare professional who cares for patients and assists doctors. An important and respected medical profession.
vocabulary.usageNote: Works in hospitals, clinics, or healthcare facilities

vocabulary.meaning: To do or to make - the most versatile verb in Korean that combines with many nouns to create compound verbs (noun + 하다). Essential for describing actions and occupations.
vocabulary.usageNote: Combines with occupation nouns: 일하다 (to work), 공부하다 (to study)

vocabulary.meaning: Two (native Korean number) - used for counting objects, people, or abstract things. Often used when referring to family members or groups.
vocabulary.usageNote: Native Korean number, used with counters and people

vocabulary.meaning: Three (native Korean number) - used for counting objects, people, or abstract things when describing quantities in family or work contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Native Korean number, changes to 세 before counters

vocabulary.meaning: Four (native Korean number) - used for counting people or objects. Commonly used when describing family size or workplace teams.
vocabulary.usageNote: Native Korean number, changes to 네 before counters

vocabulary.meaning: Family - refers to relatives living together or blood relatives. Central concept in Korean culture with strong emphasis on family bonds and roles.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used when discussing family occupations and roles

vocabulary.meaning: Father - formal and respectful term for one's father. Used when speaking about one's father to others or in formal situations.
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal term, more respectful than 아빠

grammar.meaning: Subject particles that mark the subject of a sentence. Use 이 after consonants and 가 after vowels. These particles identify who or what is performing the action or being described. Essential for creating clear, grammatically correct Korean sentences about people and their occupations.
grammar.formation: Noun + 이 (after consonant-ending nouns) / Noun + 가 (after vowel-ending nouns). Examples: 아버지 + 가 = 아버지가, 선생님 + 이 = 선생님이
grammar.usageNotes: Use when introducing new information or emphasizing the subject. Often used when asking or stating what someone does for work. Cannot be omitted in formal Korean.

grammar.meaning: A productive pattern in Korean where nouns combine with 하다 to create verbs. This pattern is essential for expressing actions and occupations. Many Korean verbs are formed this way, making it crucial for expanding vocabulary and expressing what people do for work.
grammar.formation: Action noun + 하다 → verb. Examples: 일 (work) + 하다 = 일하다 (to work), 공부 (study) + 하다 = 공부하다 (to study). Conjugates like regular verbs: 일해요 (work), 공부해요 (study).
grammar.usageNotes: Very productive pattern - many Korean verbs use this structure. Essential for describing occupations and daily activities. The 하다 part conjugates while the noun part stays the same.

grammar.meaning: Present tense polite informal conjugation used to describe current actions, habitual activities, and general states. This is the most common polite form used in everyday conversation. The choice between 아요 and 어요 depends on the vowel in the verb stem: use 아요 after stems with ㅏ or ㅗ vowels, and 어요 after stems with other vowels.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + 아요 (after ㅏ/ㅗ vowels) or 어요 (after other vowels). For verbs ending in 하다, it becomes 해요.
grammar.usageNotes: This is the standard polite form for daily conversation. Use with people you don't know well, older people, or in formal but friendly situations. More polite than informal speech but less formal than formal speech.

grammar.meaning: Object particles that mark the direct object of a sentence - the thing that receives the action of the verb. 을 is used after consonants and 를 is used after vowels. These particles clearly indicate what is being acted upon in the sentence.
grammar.formation: Attach 을 after nouns ending in consonants, 를 after nouns ending in vowels. The object particle goes directly after the noun it marks.
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for clear sentence structure in Korean. While sometimes omitted in casual speech, it's important to learn proper usage. Always comes before the verb in Korean word order.

vocabulary.meaning: Time - refers to both the concept of time and specific time periods. Used when asking about or stating the time, or referring to time in general. Essential for schedule-related conversations.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can be used with particles like 에 to indicate 'at what time'

vocabulary.meaning: Hour/o'clock - used after Sino-Korean numbers to indicate the hour. This is the formal way to tell time in Korean, used in both spoken and written contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always follows Sino-Korean numbers (일시, 이시, 삼시, etc.)

vocabulary.meaning: Minute - used after Sino-Korean numbers to indicate minutes past the hour. Essential for precise time telling and scheduling.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with Sino-Korean numbers only (일분, 이분, 삼분, etc.)

vocabulary.meaning: Morning - refers to the early part of the day, typically from sunrise until around 10 AM. Used to describe when activities happen or as a greeting context.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with 에 particle to indicate 'in the morning'

vocabulary.meaning: Lunch/midday - refers to both the midday meal and the time period around noon. Essential for discussing daily meal schedules and appointments.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can refer to both the meal and the time period

vocabulary.meaning: Evening/dinner - refers to both the evening time period (typically after 6 PM) and the evening meal. Used for scheduling evening activities and meals.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can refer to both the time period and the meal

vocabulary.meaning: Monday - first day of the work week in Korean culture. Essential for discussing weekly schedules and appointments.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with 에 particle when indicating 'on Monday'

vocabulary.meaning: Tuesday - second day of the work week. Important for describing weekly routines and scheduling.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with 에 particle when indicating 'on Tuesday'

vocabulary.meaning: Family - a group of people related by blood or marriage living together. Central concept in Korean culture, often used when discussing family schedules and activities.
Mother (formal/polite) - respectful term for one's mother, used in formal contexts or when speaking to others about your mother.

grammar.meaning: The particle 에 is used to indicate specific points in time - when an action occurs. It attaches to time expressions like hours, days, months, and time periods. This is essential for describing schedules and when activities happen. Unlike English 'at/on/in', Korean uses 에 for most specific time references.
grammar.formation: Time expression + 에 + verb. Examples: 아침에 (in the morning), 월요일에 (on Monday), 세 시에 (at 3 o'clock)
grammar.usageNotes: Use with specific times, days, time periods. Do not use with duration words or relative time expressions like 'always' or 'sometimes'

grammar.meaning: Sino-Korean numbers are Chinese-origin numbers used in Korean for formal counting, time, dates, money, and phone numbers. Unlike native Korean numbers (하나, 둘, 셋), these are used specifically with time expressions (시, 분), dates, and formal contexts. Essential for telling time and scheduling.
grammar.formation: 일 (1), 이 (2), 삼 (3), 사 (4), 오 (5), 육 (6), 칠 (7), 팔 (8), 구 (9), 십 (10). Used with 시 (hour) and 분 (minute): 일시 (1 o'clock), 이십분 (20 minutes)
grammar.usageNotes: Must use Sino-Korean numbers with time words 시 and 분. Native Korean numbers cannot be used for telling time. Remember: 일시 (1 o'clock), NOT 한 시

grammar.meaning: Location particle indicating 'at', 'in', or 'from' a place where an action occurs. Shows the setting or location of an activity. Different from 에 which indicates destination or time. 에서 emphasizes that something happens AT that place.
grammar.formation: Place/Location + 에서 + Action Verb. Used when the location is where the action takes place, not where you're going to.
grammar.usageNotes: Use with action verbs (먹어요, 공부해요, 일해요). Cannot be used with 있어요/없어요 (use 에 instead). Common mistake: using 에서 instead of 에 for destinations.

grammar.meaning: Connector meaning 'and then' or 'and' - links two actions in sequence or simultaneously. Shows that actions follow one after another or happen together. More natural than separate sentences when describing routines.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + 고 + Second action. Remove 다 from dictionary form, add 고. Can connect multiple actions: Action1 + 고 + Action2 + 고 + Action3
grammar.usageNotes: Used for sequential or simultaneous actions. First action usually completes before second begins. Cannot end a sentence with 고 alone. Very common in describing daily routines and schedules.

descriptionTranslations.de: Lerne, wie man Essen bestellt und Wünsche im Restaurant äußert

vocabulary.meaning: Menu - the list of food and drinks available at a restaurant. Used when asking to see what options are available or when referring to the restaurant's offerings.
vocabulary.usageNote: Common in restaurant contexts, can be used with particles like 메뉴를 (menu + object particle)

vocabulary.meaning: Order - the act of requesting food or drinks at a restaurant, or the items that have been ordered. Can be used as a noun or in compound verbs like 주문하다 (to order).
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential restaurant vocabulary, often used with 하다 to make it a verb

vocabulary.meaning: Beverage/drink - any liquid refreshment including water, coffee, tea, juice, or alcoholic drinks. More formal than 마실 것 and commonly used in restaurant menus.
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal term for drinks, often seen on menus and in polite conversation

vocabulary.meaning: Bill/check - the total amount to pay for a meal, or the act of calculating costs. Used when asking for the bill or when paying at restaurants.
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential for restaurant transactions, often used with 하다 (계산하다 - to pay/calculate)

vocabulary.meaning: A lot/much/many - adverb indicating large quantity or degree. Used to express abundance or intensity, commonly paired with verbs like 먹다 (to eat) or 마시다 (to drink).
vocabulary.usageNote: Very common in daily conversation, can modify verbs to show degree

vocabulary.meaning: A little/a bit - adverb indicating small quantity or degree. Used to express moderation or small amounts, often in polite contexts or when being modest.
vocabulary.usageNote: Common in polite conversation, opposite of 많이

vocabulary.meaning: Younger sibling - refers to a younger brother or sister. Previously learned family term being recycled in restaurant context examples.
vocabulary.usageNote: Review vocabulary from previous lessons

vocabulary.meaning: Korea - the country. Previously learned term being used in context of Korean food and restaurants.
vocabulary.usageNote: Review vocabulary from previous lessons, commonly used with food names

vocabulary.meaning: Person/people - human being(s). Previously learned term being recycled in restaurant contexts when talking about who is eating.
vocabulary.usageNote: Review vocabulary from previous lessons

grammar.meaning: Please give/Please provide - A polite imperative ending used when requesting something from someone, especially in service contexts like restaurants and shops. It's the formal way to ask for items or services and shows proper respect to service staff.
grammar.formation: Noun + (을/를) + 주세요. Use 을 after consonants, 를 after vowels. For items without particles, simply add 주세요 directly after the noun.
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for polite requests in Korean. Always use in service contexts. More polite than other request forms. Can be used with numbers for quantities (하나 주세요 - please give me one).

grammar.meaning: To exist/not exist or to have/not have - 있어요 indicates presence, existence, or possession while 없어요 indicates absence or lack thereof. In restaurants, commonly used to ask about menu availability or to state what is/isn't available.
grammar.formation: Subject + 이/가 + 있어요/없어요. Use 이 after consonants, 가 after vowels. For questions, use rising intonation or add question particles.
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for checking availability in restaurants. Can indicate both physical presence and possession. 있어요 can also mean 'to be located at' a place. Often used in negative responses by staff (없어요 - we don't have that).

content.description: Learn Korean numbers and how to talk about prices and money

descriptionTranslations.de: Lerne koreanische Zahlen und wie man über Preise und Geld spricht

vocabulary.meaning: One (native Korean number). Used for counting objects, age, and general counting. More natural in everyday speech than sino-Korean 일.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used when counting objects or in casual conversation

vocabulary.meaning: Two (native Korean number). Used for counting objects and in everyday situations. Changes to 두 when followed by a counter.
vocabulary.usageNote: Becomes 두 before counters (두 개, 두 명)

vocabulary.meaning: Three (native Korean number). Used for counting objects and in casual conversation. Changes to 세 when followed by a counter.
vocabulary.usageNote: Becomes 세 before counters (세 개, 세 명)

vocabulary.meaning: Ten (native Korean number). Used for counting objects up to 99 and in time expressions. Essential for forming numbers 11-19.
vocabulary.usageNote: Combined with other numbers: 열하나 (eleven), 열둘 (twelve)

vocabulary.meaning: Won (Korean currency). The basic monetary unit of South Korea. Always used with Sino-Korean numbers when discussing prices.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always follows Sino-Korean numbers: 천 원, 만 원

vocabulary.meaning: How much/How many. Essential question word for asking about prices, quantities, and amounts. Often used in shopping contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: 얼마예요? (How much is it?), 얼마나 (how much/long)

vocabulary.meaning: Money. General term for currency, cash, or financial resources. Used in various contexts from shopping to discussing finances.
vocabulary.usageNote: 돈이 있어요 (have money), 돈이 없어요 (don't have money)

vocabulary.meaning: Menu. List of food items available at a restaurant. Borrowed from English 'menu' and commonly used in dining contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - reviewing in money context

vocabulary.meaning: Beverage/drink. General term for any liquid consumed as refreshment, including both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - reviewing in pricing context

vocabulary.meaning: Calculation/bill/check. In restaurant contexts, refers to the bill or the act of paying. Essential for completing transactions.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - reviewing with money vocabulary

vocabulary.meaning: Company/office. Place of business or organization where people work. Often used when discussing occupations and work.
vocabulary.usageNote: From earlier lesson - interleaving with money contexts

vocabulary.meaning: School. Educational institution for learning. Common location reference in daily conversation and family discussions.
vocabulary.usageNote: From earlier lesson - using in number/money examples

grammar.meaning: Korean has two number systems: native Korean numbers (하나, 둘, 셋...) used for counting objects, age, and hours, and Sino-Korean numbers (일, 이, 삼...) used for dates, minutes, and money. Native Korean numbers are essential for daily counting and change form when used with counters.
grammar.formation: 하나 (1), 둘 (2), 셋 (3), 넷 (4), 다섯 (5), 여섯 (6), 일곱 (7), 여덟 (8), 아홉 (9), 열 (10). Numbers 1-4 change before counters: 한 개, 두 개, 세 개, 네 개.
grammar.usageNotes: Use for counting objects, telling age, and hours on clocks. Numbers 1-4 drop final consonant before counters. Cannot be used alone for large numbers over 99.

grammar.meaning: Sino-Korean numbers (일, 이, 삼, 사, 오, 육, 칠, 팔, 구, 십) are used for money, dates, addresses, and phone numbers. When discussing prices, always use Sino-Korean numbers followed by 원 (won). These numbers can build to very large amounts.
grammar.usageNotes: Always use with 원 for money. No spaces between number and 원. Large numbers use 만 (10,000) as base unit: 오만원 (50,000 won).

grammar.meaning: 얼마예요? is the standard polite question for asking about prices, costs, or quantities. 얼마 means 'how much/how many' and 예요 is the polite copula. This is essential for shopping and transactions in Korea.
grammar.formation: 얼마 + 예요/이에요. Use 예요 after 얼마. Response uses number + 원 + 이에요: 삼천원이에요 (It's 3,000 won). Can also ask 얼마나 for 'how much/long'.
grammar.usageNotes: Always polite form in shops. Response pattern: [price]이에요. Can add 정말 (really) for emphasis: 정말 얼마예요?

content.description: Learn shopping vocabulary and how to buy things in stores

vocabulary.meaning: A general term for shop or store. Used for small to medium-sized retail establishments. Can refer to grocery stores, clothing shops, or specialty stores.
vocabulary.usageNote: More casual than 상점 (sangjeom), commonly used in everyday conversation

vocabulary.meaning: To buy or purchase something. The basic verb for buying, used in all shopping contexts. Must be conjugated appropriately for politeness level.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 사요 in polite form, 삽니다 in formal situations

vocabulary.meaning: To sell something. Used by store owners or vendors when talking about what they sell. Common in commercial contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 팔아요 in polite form

vocabulary.meaning: General term for things, items, or goods. Used when referring to merchandise or objects for sale. More formal than just saying '것' (thing).
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used in shopping contexts to refer to products or merchandise

vocabulary.meaning: To be big or large in size. Used to describe physical dimensions of objects, places, or abstract concepts like importance.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 커요 in polite form, often used when comparing sizes

vocabulary.meaning: To be small or little in size. Opposite of 크다. Used for physical objects, spaces, or quantities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 작아요 in polite form

vocabulary.meaning: To be expensive or costly. Essential shopping vocabulary for discussing prices. Often used when complaining about high prices.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 비싸요, often used with 너무 (too) for emphasis

vocabulary.meaning: To be cheap or inexpensive. Used to describe good prices or bargains. Positive connotation when shopping.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 싸요, often used to express satisfaction with prices

vocabulary.meaning: Family members collectively. Refers to one's immediate family including parents, siblings, and children living together.
vocabulary.usageNote: Review vocabulary from previous lessons, commonly used when talking about shopping for family

vocabulary.meaning: Three (native Korean number). Used when counting objects, people, or items. Essential for shopping and quantities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Review vocabulary, used with counters and for counting items

vocabulary.meaning: Four (native Korean number). Continues the counting sequence, essential for shopping and expressing quantities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Review vocabulary, follows the native Korean number pattern

grammar.meaning: How much is it? / How much does it cost? This is the standard polite way to ask about prices when shopping. Essential for any purchasing situation. Used when pointing to an item or after mentioning what you want to buy.
grammar.formation: 얼마 (how much) + 예요 (polite copula) = 얼마예요? Can also be used as 얼마입니까? in formal situations.
grammar.usageNotes: Always used when asking about prices. Response typically uses 원 (won) currency. Can be used for any item or service.

grammar.meaning: Location particle indicating where an action takes place. Different from 에 which indicates destination or specific time. 에서 shows the location where you DO something - shop, eat, work, etc.
grammar.formation: Noun + 에서 + action verb. The noun indicates the place where the action happens.
grammar.usageNotes: Used with action verbs (사다, 먹다, 일하다). Don't confuse with 에 (destination/time). Essential for saying where you shop or do activities.

vocabulary.meaning: Fresh, recently harvested or prepared. Used primarily for food items like vegetables, fruits, meat, and fish to describe their quality and freshness.

vocabulary.meaning: Delicious, tasty. The most common adjective used to describe good-tasting food. Essential for expressing satisfaction with meals and making food recommendations.

vocabulary.meaning: Supermarket or grocery store. Modern retail establishment that sells packaged foods, household items, and daily necessities. Borrowed from English 'mart'.

vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates as 비싸요 in polite form

vocabulary.meaning: Company, corporation. Business organization where people work. Used when discussing workplace or employment context.

grammar.pattern: Review and Integration of All Patterns
grammar.meaning: This lesson integrates all previously learned grammar patterns in natural contexts. Students practice combining 얼마예요?, 에서, 을/를, 주세요, 아요/어요, and 하다 verbs in realistic shopping scenarios. The focus is on fluent combination of patterns rather than learning new individual structures.
grammar.formation: Combine multiple patterns naturally: Location에서 + Object을/를 + Verb아요/어요, 얼마예요?, Object 주세요
grammar.usageNotes: Practice flowing conversations using multiple patterns together. Focus on natural rhythm and appropriate particle usage.

descriptionTranslations.de: Lerne Namen von häufigen Orten und grundlegende Ortsangaben

vocabulary.meaning: A financial institution where people deposit money, get loans, and conduct banking services. Essential for daily life in Korea.

vocabulary.meaning: A medical facility where doctors treat patients and provide healthcare services. Important to know for health emergencies.

vocabulary.meaning: Library where books are borrowed, studied, and research is conducted. Public libraries are very popular in Korea.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used when talking about studying or borrowing books

vocabulary.usageNote: Used when talking about outdoor activities or exercise

vocabulary.meaning: Subway station where underground trains stop to pick up and drop off passengers. Essential for navigation in Korean cities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used when giving directions or talking about transportation

vocabulary.meaning: Front, in front of. A location word indicating the area directly before something. Used frequently in Korean for giving directions.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always used with 에 particle when indicating location

vocabulary.meaning: Side, next to. A location word indicating the area beside something. Commonly used for describing relative positions.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always used with 에 particle when indicating location

vocabulary.meaning: Time or hour. Previously learned when discussing schedules, now used in context of business hours and opening times.
O'clock, hour marker. Previously learned for telling time, now used for business hours and schedules.
Minute. Previously learned for time expressions, now used in context of walking distances and precise timing.
Store, shop. Previously learned in shopping context, now used when describing city locations and commercial areas.
Company, office building. Previously learned in work context, now used as a location reference point in the city.

grammar.meaning: Location particle indicating static location or destination. Used to express 'at', 'in', or 'to' a place. This is different from 에서 which indicates where an action takes place. 에 simply indicates location or destination without implying action.
grammar.formation: Place/Location + 에 + verb (usually 있어요/가요/와요)
grammar.usageNotes: Use 에 for static location (being at a place) or destination (going to a place). Do not use for actions happening at a location - that requires 에서.

grammar.meaning: Location particle indicating where an action takes place. Means 'at', 'in', or 'from' when describing the location of an action. Different from 에 which is for static location - 에서 emphasizes that something happens at that place.
grammar.formation: Place/Location + 에서 + action verb
grammar.usageNotes: Use 에서 when an action happens at a location. Also used to mean 'from' when indicating starting point of movement. Previously learned but now expanding usage to city places.

content.description: Learn transportation vocabulary and how to express using different transport

descriptionTranslations.de: Lerne Verkehrsvokabular und wie man die Nutzung verschiedener Transportmittel ausdrückt

vocabulary.meaning: A large public vehicle that carries passengers along a fixed route. Used for city transportation and longer distances. In Korea, buses are color-coded: blue for regular city buses, red for express buses, green for local buses.
vocabulary.usageNote: Most common form of public transportation in Korean cities

vocabulary.meaning: Subway or underground train system. A rapid transit system that runs underground in major cities. Seoul has an extensive subway network with numbered lines and color coding.
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential transportation in Seoul and Busan

vocabulary.meaning: Taxi cab - a private vehicle for hire with a driver that takes you directly to your destination. In Korea, taxis are usually orange, silver, or black. More expensive but convenient for door-to-door service.
vocabulary.usageNote: Good for short distances or when carrying heavy items

vocabulary.meaning: Automobile or car - a personal motor vehicle with four wheels used for transportation. Can refer to any type of car including sedans, SUVs, etc. More formal term than '차'.
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal term for car, used in official contexts

vocabulary.meaning: Bicycle - a two-wheeled vehicle powered by pedaling. Environmentally friendly transportation popular for short distances and exercise. Korea has bike rental systems in many cities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Popular for exercise and short-distance travel

vocabulary.meaning: To ride, take, or board a vehicle. Used for getting on or using any form of transportation including buses, trains, cars, bicycles. Essential verb for discussing transportation.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with transportation vehicles, takes object particle 을/를

vocabulary.meaning: To walk - to move by foot at a regular pace. Used for traveling short distances on foot or for exercise. The basic form of human locomotion.
vocabulary.usageNote: Irregular verb - stem changes to 걸어

vocabulary.meaning: Family members including parents, siblings, and children living together. The basic social unit in Korean society with strong emphasis on respect and hierarchy.
House or home - the place where one lives with family. Can refer to the physical building or the concept of home as a place of belonging.
School - an educational institution where students learn. Can refer to elementary, middle, high school, or university.
Hospital - a medical facility where doctors treat patients. Place to go when sick or injured.
Mother - respectful term for one's mother or someone else's mother. More formal than 엄마.

grammar.meaning: Particle indicating means or method, similar to 'by' or 'with' in English. Used to show the tool, method, or means by which an action is performed. After consonants use '으로', after vowels use '로'. When discussing transportation, it means 'by means of' that vehicle.
grammar.formation: Noun + 으로/로. Use '으로' after consonants (except ㄹ), use '로' after vowels and ㄹ. Examples: 버스로 (by bus), 지하철로 (by subway), 자동차로 (by car).
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for expressing transportation methods. Different from 에 which shows destination. Can also indicate direction or material something is made from.

grammar.meaning: To ride or take a vehicle. 타다 is the verb meaning 'to ride/board' and requires the object particle 을/를 before it. Used specifically for vehicles and transportation. Essential pattern for expressing how you travel.
grammar.formation: Transportation vehicle + 을/를 + 타다. Use '을' after consonants, '를' after vowels. Examples: 버스를 타다 (take the bus), 지하철을 타다 (take the subway).
grammar.usageNotes: Always use object particle with 타다. Can be combined with other particles like 에서 to show where you board. Present tense: 타요, past tense: 탔어요.

content.description: Learn how to ask for and understand basic directions

descriptionTranslations.de: Lerne, wie man nach dem Weg fragt und grundlegende Wegbeschreibungen versteht

vocabulary.meaning: Question word meaning 'where'; used to ask about locations, places, or positions. Essential for direction-related conversations and location inquiries.
vocabulary.usageNote: Always used in questions, often followed by particles like 에 or 에서

vocabulary.meaning: Going straight ahead; moving in a direct line without turning left or right. Commonly used when giving directions to indicate continuing forward.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with 하세요 to give directions: 직진하세요 (go straight)

vocabulary.meaning: Left side or left direction; used to indicate the leftward direction when giving or following directions. Essential for navigation vocabulary.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with 으로 particle: 왼쪽으로 (toward the left)

vocabulary.meaning: Right side or right direction; used to indicate the rightward direction when giving or following directions. Paired with 왼쪽 for complete directional vocabulary.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with 으로 particle: 오른쪽으로 (toward the right)

vocabulary.meaning: Front side or forward direction; indicates the area or direction that is ahead. Used in directions to specify moving toward the front of something.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can be used with location particles; related to 앞 (front) learned previously

vocabulary.meaning: To be far or distant; describes a place or object that is at a considerable distance. Used to express that something requires significant time or effort to reach.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 멀어요 in polite form; opposite of 가깝다 (close)

vocabulary.meaning: To be close or near; describes a place or object that is at a short distance. Used to express that something can be reached easily or quickly.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 가까워요 in polite form; opposite of 멀다 (far)

vocabulary.meaning: Subway or underground railway system; public transportation that runs underground. Previously learned transportation method, now used in direction contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with 을/를 타다 for riding, now also in location contexts

vocabulary.meaning: Bus; public transportation vehicle that travels on roads. Previously learned as transportation method, now appearing in direction-asking contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Commonly used with transportation verbs and location particles

vocabulary.meaning: To walk; to move on foot from one place to another. Previously learned transportation method, now essential for understanding walking directions.
vocabulary.usageNote: Conjugates to 걸어요 in polite form; fundamental for direction-giving

vocabulary.meaning: Time; used to express duration or specific points in time. Previously learned in time expressions, now used to ask about travel time in directions.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with numbers and time-related questions; essential for duration inquiries

grammar.meaning: A question pattern meaning 'Where is...?' or 'Where is it located?'. This is the fundamental structure for asking about the location of places, objects, or people. The particle 에 indicates location, and 있어요 means 'to exist/be located'. This pattern is essential for navigation and finding places.
grammar.formation: 어디 + 에 + 있어요? - Combine the question word 어디 (where), the location particle 에, and the existence verb 있어요 (polite form of 있다)
grammar.usageNotes: Always used as a question. Can be modified to 어디에 있습니까? for more formal situations. The subject being asked about is often omitted when clear from context.

grammar.meaning: A question pattern meaning 'How do I get there?' or 'How do I go?'. This asks about the method or way to reach a destination. 어떻게 means 'how' and 가요 is the polite form of 가다 (to go). This is essential for asking about transportation methods and routes.
grammar.formation: 어떻게 + 가요? - Combine the question word 어떻게 (how) with the polite form of 가다 (to go)
grammar.usageNotes: Often used after asking where something is located. Can be followed up with specific transportation questions. The destination is usually established in previous context.

vocabulary.meaning: Station - refers to train stations, subway stations, or any transportation hub. Used when referring to meeting points or departure/arrival locations for public transport.

grammar.meaning: This pattern expresses movement or duration 'from (place A) to (place B)'. 에서 marks the starting point and 에까지 marks the endpoint. It's used to describe routes, journeys, or any movement between two locations. The pattern emphasizes the complete path or duration of travel.
grammar.formation: Starting place + 에서 + ending place + 에까지. For places ending in consonants, use 에서/에까지 directly. This pattern is always used together as a pair to show the complete route.
grammar.usageNotes: Always use both parts together. Cannot use 에서 without 에까지 when expressing 'from-to' movement. Different from simple 에 (to) because it emphasizes the starting point as well as destination.

grammar.meaning: This expression means 'How long does it take?' or 'How much time does it take?'. It's used to ask about the duration of travel, activities, or any time-consuming process. 시간 (time) + 이 (subject particle) + 얼마나 (how much) + 걸려요 (take/cost). Essential for planning journeys and understanding schedules.
grammar.formation: 시간이 얼마나 걸려요? (question form) / 시간이 + time duration + 걸려요 (answer form). To answer: [number] + 시간 (hours) or [number] + 분 (minutes) + 걸려요.
grammar.usageNotes: Always include 시간이 in the question. For answers, you can specify hours (시간), minutes (분), or both. Use Sino-Korean numbers for time duration.

vocabulary.meaning: Weather - refers to atmospheric conditions at a specific time and place. Used in daily conversation to discuss current conditions or make small talk.
vocabulary.usageNote: Essential word for weather discussions, often used with descriptive adjectives

vocabulary.meaning: To be clear/sunny - describes weather with no clouds and bright sunshine. Also used metaphorically for clear water or clear mind.
vocabulary.usageNote: Changes to 맑아요 in polite form, commonly used for pleasant weather

vocabulary.meaning: To be cloudy/overcast - describes weather with gray clouds covering the sky. Can also describe unclear vision or muddy water.
vocabulary.usageNote: Changes to 흐려요 in polite form, indicates potential for rain

vocabulary.meaning: Rain - precipitation in the form of water droplets. Essential weather vocabulary used with various verbs like 오다 (to come) or 내리다 (to fall).
vocabulary.usageNote: Often combined with other words: 비가 오다 (it's raining)

vocabulary.meaning: Wind - moving air, can range from gentle breeze to strong gusts. Also used metaphorically for wishes or desires (소망/바람).
vocabulary.usageNote: Often described with adjectives like 강한 (strong) or 시원한 (cool)

vocabulary.meaning: To be hot - describes high temperature weather that makes one feel warm or uncomfortable. Specifically refers to air temperature, not object temperature.
vocabulary.usageNote: Changes to 더워요 in polite form, used for weather and ambient temperature

vocabulary.meaning: To be cold - describes low temperature weather that makes one feel chilly. Refers to ambient temperature affecting comfort level.
vocabulary.usageNote: Changes to 추워요 in polite form, commonly used in winter weather descriptions

vocabulary.meaning: Order - placing a request for food, drinks, or services. Essential vocabulary for restaurant interactions and customer service situations.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used with 하다 to make orders: 주문하다

grammar.meaning: Pattern for stating that weather 'is' or 'is not' a certain way. 이다 is used to identify or describe states, while 아니다 is used for negation. With weather adjectives, this creates basic descriptive sentences about current conditions.
grammar.formation: Subject + adjective stem + 이에요/예요 (polite) or 이다/다 (plain). For negation: Subject + adjective stem + 이/가 아니에요
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for basic weather descriptions. Use 이에요 after consonants, 예요 after vowels. Weather adjectives often drop the 다 and add appropriate endings.

grammar.pattern: Present tense weather descriptions with 가/이
grammar.meaning: Using subject particles 가/이 to mark the subject in weather descriptions. 가 follows consonants, 이 follows vowels. This creates natural-sounding weather statements that focus on the weather as the subject performing the action or being in a state.
grammar.formation: 날씨 + 가 + adjective + 요, or Weather noun + 가/이 + verb + 요. Example: 비가 와요 (rain is coming), 바람이 불어요 (wind is blowing)
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for natural weather descriptions. Choose 가 after consonants (날씨가, 비가) and 이 after vowels (바람이). Often combined with weather verbs like 오다, 불다.

vocabulary.usageNote: Associated with hiking, leaf viewing, and comfortable outdoor weather

vocabulary.usageNote: Often paired with 춥다 (cold) and winter activities like skiing

vocabulary.usageNote: Irregular ㅂ verb - stem changes when conjugated (돕다 → 도와요)

vocabulary.meaning: To be cold - an irregular ㅂ verb describing cold temperature or feeling cold. Changes to 추워요 in polite form.
vocabulary.usageNote: Irregular ㅂ verb - 춥다 → 추워요, commonly used with winter and cold weather

vocabulary.meaning: To be hot - an irregular ㅂ verb describing hot temperature or feeling hot. Changes to 더워요 in polite form.
vocabulary.usageNote: Irregular ㅂ verb - 덥다 → 더워요, commonly used with summer weather

vocabulary.meaning: Snow - frozen precipitation that falls in winter, creating white landscapes. In Korean culture, snow is associated with beauty and winter activities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can also mean 'eye' but context makes meaning clear

vocabulary.meaning: To swim - a compound verb combining 수영 (swimming) with 하다 (to do). A popular summer activity to cool down in hot weather.
vocabulary.usageNote: Regular 하다 verb, often used with summer activities and locations like 바다 (sea) or 수영장 (pool)

vocabulary.meaning: Ski/skiing - winter sport equipment and activity. Borrowed word from English, commonly used with 타다 (to ride) or 하다 (to do).
vocabulary.usageNote: Loanword from English, typically used as 스키를 타다 (to ski)

grammar.meaning: A group of Korean verbs and adjectives ending in ㅂ that undergo stem changes when conjugated. The ㅂ is dropped and 우 or 오 is added depending on the vowel harmony rules. This pattern affects many common words including 춥다, 덥다, 돕다, and others.
grammar.formation: Remove ㅂ from stem + 워요/와요. If stem has ㅏ or ㅗ vowel → 와요. All other vowels → 워요. Examples: 춥다 → 추워요, 덥다 → 더워요, 돕다 → 도와요
grammar.usageNotes: Very common pattern affecting everyday vocabulary. Must memorize which verbs follow this pattern as it's not predictable from the dictionary form. Essential for natural Korean speech.

grammar.meaning: Expressions used to describe activities that happen during specific seasons. Uses the particle 에 to mark the time/season when activities occur, combined with seasonal vocabulary and activity verbs to create natural descriptions of what people do throughout the year.
grammar.formation: Season + 에 + activity verb. Examples: 봄에 꽃을 봐요 (In spring, we see flowers), 여름에 수영해요 (In summer, we swim). Can be expanded with location particles.
grammar.usageNotes: Essential pattern for describing seasonal routines and preferences. Often combined with location particles (에서) and object particles (을/를) for complete sentences. Natural way to talk about annual activities and seasonal traditions.

content.description: Express how weather affects mood and plans using conditional expressions and cause-effect patterns

descriptionTranslations.de: Drücken Sie aus, wie das Wetter Stimmung und Pläne beeinflusst, mit bedingten Ausdrücken und Ursache-Wirkungs-Mustern

vocabulary.meaning: Mood, feeling, or emotional state. Used to describe how someone feels emotionally at a particular moment, often influenced by external factors like weather, events, or circumstances.
vocabulary.usageNote: Commonly used with 좋다/나쁘다 to express good/bad mood

vocabulary.meaning: To be depressed, gloomy, or melancholy. Describes a deeper emotional state than just being sad, often associated with overcast weather or prolonged negative feelings.
vocabulary.usageNote: ㅎ irregular adjective - conjugates as 우울해요

vocabulary.meaning: To feel refreshed, invigorated, or pleasantly cool. Often used to describe the feeling from fresh air, cool breeze, or pleasant weather conditions.
vocabulary.usageNote: ㅎ irregular adjective - conjugates as 상쾌해요

vocabulary.meaning: To be humid, damp, or moist. Describes weather conditions with high moisture content in the air, making it feel sticky and uncomfortable.
vocabulary.usageNote: ㅂ irregular adjective - conjugates as 습해요

vocabulary.meaning: To be dry, arid, or lacking moisture. Used for weather conditions or air quality that lacks humidity, often causing discomfort to skin or breathing.
vocabulary.usageNote: ㅎ irregular adjective - conjugates as 건조해요

vocabulary.meaning: Indoor space or the interior of a building. Refers to any enclosed area inside a structure, as opposed to outdoor spaces.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with activities or locations, contrasts with 실외 (outdoor)

vocabulary.meaning: Outdoor space or open air. Refers to any area outside of buildings, including parks, streets, or natural environments where activities take place in the open.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with activities like 야외 활동 (outdoor activities)

vocabulary.meaning: Weather conditions at a particular time and place, including temperature, precipitation, wind, and atmospheric conditions.
To be hot or warm in temperature. Used to describe weather, objects, or sensations of heat.
To be cold in temperature. Used to describe weather, objects, or sensations of cold.
Rain or precipitation in the form of water drops falling from clouds.

grammar.meaning: Comprehensive causal connective expressing cause and reason, meaning 'because' or 'so'. This pattern connects two clauses where the first clause provides the reason or cause for the second clause. Unlike 때문에 which focuses on external causes, 아/어서 emphasizes the natural flow from cause to effect and is commonly used in spoken Korean.
grammar.formation: Verb/adjective stem + 아/어서. Use 아서 after ㅏ,ㅗ vowel stems; 어서 after other vowels. For 하다 verbs, use 해서. Cannot be used with commands, suggestions, or future tense in the second clause.
grammar.usageNotes: Used for natural cause-effect relationships. The second clause cannot contain commands (으세요), suggestions (ㅂ시다), or future intentions. More natural than 때문에 in conversation.

grammar.meaning: Pattern for expressing feelings and emotional states, literally meaning 'mood/feeling is [adjective]'. This construction is essential for describing how external factors like weather affect one's emotional state. 기분 represents one's temporary emotional condition, while the following adjective describes the specific feeling.
grammar.formation: 기분이 + adjective (좋다/나쁘다/우울하다/상쾌하다 etc.). The particle 이 marks 기분 as the subject, and any descriptive adjective can follow to specify the emotional state.
grammar.usageNotes: More specific than just using adjectives alone. Shows that you're talking about emotional feelings rather than physical sensations. Commonly paired with causal expressions to explain why you feel a certain way.

vocabulary.meaning: A detailed scheme or arrangement for accomplishing something; plans for future activities or events. Used when discussing intentions, schedules, or organized activities.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with verbs like 세우다 (to make) or 바꾸다 (to change)

vocabulary.meaning: Weather forecast; a prediction of future weather conditions based on meteorological data. Essential vocabulary for planning activities based on expected weather.
vocabulary.usageNote: Usually appears as 날씨 예보 (weather forecast)

vocabulary.meaning: To cancel or call off; to revoke a previously made plan or arrangement. Used when plans need to be abandoned due to circumstances like weather.
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal verb, often used in official contexts or polite conversation

vocabulary.meaning: To postpone or delay; to put off an event or activity to a later time. Different from canceling as the plan will still happen, just at a different time.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used when rescheduling rather than completely canceling

vocabulary.meaning: A picnic or outdoor excursion; a recreational trip usually involving eating outdoors. Common activity that depends heavily on good weather conditions.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with 가다 (to go) - 소풍 가다

vocabulary.meaning: An umbrella; a portable shelter used for protection from rain or sun. Essential item when planning outdoor activities during uncertain weather.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can be used with 가져가다 (to bring/take) or 쓰다 (to use/wear)

vocabulary.meaning: Probably, perhaps, maybe; an adverb expressing uncertainty or probability. Used when making predictions or expressing likelihood about future events.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with future tense or conditional expressions

vocabulary.meaning: Weather; atmospheric conditions including temperature, precipitation, and wind
Rain; precipitation in the form of water drops

grammar.meaning: Conditional particle meaning 'if' or 'when'. Used to express conditions, hypothetical situations, or future possibilities. Attached to verb stems to create conditional clauses that set up a condition for the main clause.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + 으면 (after consonant) / 면 (after vowel or ㄹ). For adjectives: adjective stem + (으)면. For nouns: noun + (이)면
grammar.usageNotes: Used for real conditions (likely to happen) and hypothetical conditions. The main clause often contains suggestions, plans, or consequences. Cannot be used with past tense in the conditional clause.

grammar.meaning: Expression meaning 'want to' or 'would like to'. Used to express personal desires, wishes, or intentions. Attached to verb stems to indicate what the speaker wants to do.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + 고 싶다. Conjugates like an adjective: 고 싶어요 (polite), 고 싶습니다 (formal), 고 싶어 (casual)
grammar.usageNotes: Only used for the speaker's own desires in statements. For questions about others' desires, use 고 싶어요? Can be used with all tenses. Often combined with conditional expressions.

content.description: Express preferences for seasons and weather, give detailed reasons using multiple grammar patterns in natural conversation

descriptionTranslations.de: Drücken Sie Vorlieben für Jahreszeiten und Wetter aus, geben Sie detaillierte Gründe mit mehreren Grammatikmustern in natürlicher Unterhaltung

vocabulary.meaning: To like, to prefer. Used to express positive feelings toward things, activities, or seasons. More general than 선호하다 (prefer) and commonly used in daily conversation.
vocabulary.usageNote: Use with 을/를 for objects, or can be followed by nouns directly

vocabulary.meaning: To dislike, to hate. Expresses negative feelings toward something. Opposite of 좋아하다. Can range from mild dislike to strong aversion depending on context.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with 을/를, can express both mild and strong dislike

vocabulary.meaning: Reason, cause. Used when explaining why something happens or why someone does something. Essential for giving explanations and justifications.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often followed by particles 가/이 or 는/은, commonly used with (으)니까

vocabulary.meaning: Especially, particularly. Used to emphasize something specific among other things. Adds emphasis and shows what stands out most.
vocabulary.usageNote: Usually placed at the beginning of a sentence or before the emphasized item

vocabulary.meaning: Completely, totally, entirely. Used to show that something is done to the fullest extent or without exception. Stronger than just 아주 (very).
vocabulary.usageNote: Can modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs for emphasis

vocabulary.meaning: To compare. Used when examining similarities and differences between two or more things, people, or situations.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with 와/과 (with) to show what is being compared

vocabulary.meaning: To be different, to differ. Used to show that things are not the same. Can describe differences in appearance, characteristics, or opinions.
vocabulary.usageNote: Changes to 달라요 in polite form due to ㄹ irregular pattern

vocabulary.meaning: Plan, schedule. Refers to organized arrangements for future activities or events, especially those that depend on weather conditions.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - used when discussing weather-dependent activities

vocabulary.meaning: Weather forecast, prediction. Information about expected weather conditions used for planning activities.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - commonly used with 날씨 (weather)

vocabulary.meaning: Mood, feeling. Emotional state that can be affected by weather, seasons, and various circumstances.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - often used with adjectives like 좋다/나쁘다

vocabulary.meaning: To be refreshing, invigorating. Describes pleasant, crisp weather conditions that make one feel energized and comfortable.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - commonly used to describe spring and fall weather

vocabulary.meaning: To be hot (weather). Describes high temperature conditions, typically uncomfortable summer heat.
vocabulary.usageNote: From previous lesson - ㅂ irregular verb, becomes 더워요

grammar.meaning: Because, since. Used to give reasons or explanations for actions, decisions, or situations. Shows cause-and-effect relationships. More formal than 아/어서 and can be used when the speaker wants to emphasize the reason or when giving advice. Can be used with both verbs and adjectives.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + (으)니까: If stem ends in vowel or ㄹ, add 니까. If stem ends in consonant, add 으니까. Adjective stem + (으)니까: Same rules as verbs. Past tense: Add 았/었 before (으)니까.
grammar.usageNotes: Use when explaining reasons for decisions, especially those involving planning or preferences. Can be used in formal situations unlike 아/어서. The speaker's opinion or decision typically comes in the main clause.

grammar.meaning: More than, compared to. Used to make comparisons between two things, showing that one has more of a quality than another. Essential for expressing preferences and describing differences between seasons or weather conditions.
grammar.formation: Noun + 보다 + 더 + adjective/adverb. The thing being compared to comes first with 보다, followed by 더 and the comparative quality.
grammar.usageNotes: 보다 marks what you're comparing against. 더 emphasizes the comparison. Can be used with any adjective or adverb. Often used when expressing seasonal preferences or weather comparisons.

grammar.meaning: Using two or more grammar patterns together in natural conversation. This includes combining (으)니까 with 고 싶다, using 보다 더 with preference verbs, and linking conditional (으)면 with reason (으)니까 for complex explanations.
grammar.formation: Various combinations: Pattern1 + Pattern2 in logical sequence. Common combinations: (으)니까 + 고 싶다 (because + want), (으)면 + (으)니까 (if + because), 보다 더 + 좋아하다 (more than + like).
grammar.usageNotes: Essential for natural conversation flow. Start with simple combinations before attempting complex ones. Pay attention to word order and particle usage. Practice with familiar vocabulary first.

content.description: Learn essential body part vocabulary and how to describe physical sensations using 아프다 and related expressions

descriptionTranslations.de: Lernen Sie wichtige Körperteil-Vokabeln und wie man körperliche Empfindungen mit 아프다 und verwandten Ausdrücken beschreibt

vocabulary.meaning: Head - the uppermost part of the body containing the brain, eyes, ears, nose, and mouth. Used in various expressions beyond anatomy.
vocabulary.usageNote: Also used in expressions like 머리가 좋다 (to be smart)

vocabulary.meaning: Stomach/belly - the part of the body containing digestive organs. Commonly referenced when discussing hunger or stomach pain.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used with 고프다 (hungry) or 아프다 (painful)

vocabulary.meaning: Leg - the limb used for walking and standing. Also can refer to bridge in different contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Context determines whether it means leg or bridge

vocabulary.meaning: Arm - the upper limb of the body, from shoulder to hand. Essential for daily activities and gestures.
Hand - the part of the arm below the wrist, used for grasping and manipulation. Very important in Korean culture for greetings and respect.
vocabulary.usageNote: Featured in many cultural expressions and etiquette rules

vocabulary.meaning: Foot - the part of the leg below the ankle, used for standing and walking. Important in Korean customs regarding shoes and cleanliness.
vocabulary.usageNote: Significant in Korean culture - shoes removed in homes

vocabulary.meaning: Back - the rear part of the torso from shoulders to waist. Often mentioned in contexts of pain or carrying things.
vocabulary.usageNote: Commonly used with 아프다 due to modern lifestyle

vocabulary.meaning: To hurt, to be painful, to ache - describes physical pain or discomfort. Can be used with body parts or emotional contexts.
vocabulary.usageNote: Takes 이/가 particle with body parts: 머리가 아파요

vocabulary.meaning: Market - a place where goods are bought and sold, typically fresh produce and local items.
To be fresh - describes food, air, or ideas that are new and not stale.
To be delicious, tasty - describes food that has good flavor.

grammar.meaning: This pattern expresses that a specific body part hurts or is painful. 이/가 is the subject particle that marks which body part is experiencing pain. 아프다 is an adjective meaning 'to be painful' and conjugates like other descriptive verbs. This is the most natural way to express physical pain in Korean, more commonly used than alternatives.
grammar.formation: Body part + 이 (if ending in consonant) / 가 (if ending in vowel) + 아프다. Conjugate 아프다 according to politeness level: 아파요 (polite), 아프다 (plain), 아픕니다 (formal).
grammar.usageNotes: Always use 이/가 particle, never 은/는. Can be used with specific body parts or general areas. More natural than saying '내가 아프다' for specific pain.

content.description: Expand vocabulary for common health symptoms and learn to express degrees of illness using 많이, 조금, 너무

descriptionTranslations.de: Erweitern Sie Vokabeln für häufige Gesundheitssymptome und lernen Sie Krankheitsgrade mit 많이, 조금, 너무 auszudrücken

vocabulary.meaning: To be sick, to hurt (polite form). Used to describe general illness or when asking about someone's health condition. More formal than 아프다.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used in polite conversation when discussing health

vocabulary.meaning: Cold, common cold. The most common illness, characterized by runny nose, cough, and mild fever. Often used with 걸리다 (to catch) or 앓다 (to suffer from).
vocabulary.usageNote: 감기에 걸리다 means 'to catch a cold'

vocabulary.meaning: Fever, high body temperature. Used to describe elevated temperature due to illness. Often combined with 나다 (to develop) or 있다 (to have).
vocabulary.usageNote: 열이 나다 means 'to have a fever'

vocabulary.meaning: Cough, the act of coughing. A common symptom of respiratory illness. Can be used with 하다 as a verb (기침하다 - to cough) or as a standalone noun.
vocabulary.usageNote: 기침이 나다 means 'to have a cough'

vocabulary.meaning: Throat, neck. Body part that can become sore during illness. Often used in expressions like 목이 아프다 (sore throat) or 목감기 (throat cold).
vocabulary.usageNote: 목이 아프다 is very common for describing throat pain

vocabulary.meaning: A lot, much, very much. Degree adverb used to intensify adjectives or verbs. Indicates a high degree or intensity of something, stronger than 조금 but more moderate than 너무.
vocabulary.usageNote: Used before adjectives to show high intensity

vocabulary.meaning: A little, slightly, somewhat. Degree adverb indicating mild intensity or small amount. Used to soften statements and show that something is not severe.
vocabulary.usageNote: Often used to be polite when describing problems

vocabulary.meaning: Too much, excessively, very. Degree adverb indicating excessive intensity, often with negative connotation. Stronger than 많이 and suggests something beyond the normal or acceptable level.
vocabulary.usageNote: Can indicate both positive intensity and problematic excess

vocabulary.meaning: Head. Body part that commonly aches during illness or stress. Previously learned vocabulary being recycled in health contexts.
Stomach, belly. Body part that can hurt due to various reasons including illness or eating problems. Previously learned vocabulary being recycled.
Calculation, bill, payment. Previously learned vocabulary being recycled to maintain exposure.
To buy, to purchase. Previously learned vocabulary being recycled in health-related contexts.

grammar.meaning: Degree adverbs that modify adjectives to express intensity levels. 많이 indicates high intensity (a lot/very much), 조금 indicates low intensity (a little/slightly), and 너무 indicates excessive intensity (too much/excessively). These adverbs are placed directly before the adjective they modify and are essential for expressing precise degrees of symptoms or conditions.
grammar.formation: Subject + 많이/조금/너무 + adjective + 해요/아요/어요
grammar.usageNotes: 많이 is neutral-positive, 조금 is mild/polite, 너무 often implies excess or problems. Use 조금 to be polite about complaints.

grammar.meaning: Expression meaning 'it seems like' or 'I think that' used to express uncertainty or make tentative conclusions based on observation or feeling. This pattern allows speakers to express opinions or diagnoses without being too direct or certain, which is especially important in Korean culture for politeness. The (으)ㄴ ending conjugates based on whether the verb stem ends in a consonant or vowel.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + (으)ㄴ 것 같아요. Use ㄴ after vowel-ending stems, 은 after consonant-ending stems
grammar.usageNotes: Shows politeness by not being too definitive. Very common in medical or uncertain situations. More polite than stating facts directly.

vocabulary.meaning: Hospital - a medical facility where patients receive treatment from doctors and nurses. Used for serious illnesses, injuries, or when pharmacy treatment is insufficient

vocabulary.meaning: Pharmacy/drugstore - a place where medications and basic health products are sold. Pharmacists can provide advice for minor health issues

vocabulary.meaning: Doctor/physician - a medical professional who diagnoses illnesses and prescribes treatment. Requires respectful language when speaking to or about them

vocabulary.usageNote: Use respectful speech when addressing nurses

vocabulary.meaning: Pharmacist - a professional who dispenses medications and provides advice about drug usage and side effects
vocabulary.usageNote: Can provide medical advice for minor conditions

vocabulary.meaning: Medicine/medication - substances used to treat illness or pain. Can be prescription or over-the-counter
vocabulary.usageNote: Generic term for all types of medicine

vocabulary.meaning: Medical examination/consultation - the process of a doctor examining and diagnosing a patient's condition
vocabulary.usageNote: Formal medical term used in hospitals and clinics

vocabulary.meaning: Prescription - a written order from a doctor specifying what medication a patient should take
vocabulary.usageNote: Required for obtaining certain medications at pharmacy

vocabulary.meaning: Library - a place where books and other materials are kept for public use
Post office - a facility for postal services including sending mail and packages
A lot/much - adverb indicating a large amount or degree
A little/somewhat - adverb indicating a small amount or degree

grammar.meaning: Formal polite ending used in professional settings, with strangers, or in formal situations. This is more formal than 해요/해요 and shows respect and distance. 습니다 is used after consonants, ㅂ니다 after vowels.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + 습니다 (after consonant) or ㅂ니다 (after vowel). For adjectives: adjective stem + 습니다/ㅂ니다. Past tense: 었/았습니다
grammar.usageNotes: Use in hospitals, banks, government offices, with elderly people, in job interviews. More formal than 해요 endings. Essential for medical consultations.

grammar.meaning: Go/come in order to do something. This pattern expresses purpose - you go somewhere with the intention of doing a specific action. 으러 attaches to action verbs to show the reason for movement.
grammar.formation: Action verb stem + 으러 + 가다/오다. If the verb stem ends in a vowel or ㄹ, just add 러. Examples: 먹다 → 먹으러, 사다 → 사러, 만들다 → 만들러
grammar.usageNotes: Only used with action verbs (not descriptive adjectives). Very common for expressing purpose of going somewhere. Different from ~기 위해 which is more formal.

grammar.meaning: Past tense form in polite informal speech. Used to describe completed actions or past experiences, essential for discussing previous health conditions or treatments received.

grammar.meaning: If/when conditional expression. Used to express conditions, hypothetical situations, or general truths. When the condition in the first clause is met, the result in the second clause follows. This pattern can express both real conditions (things that actually happen) and hypothetical conditions (things that might happen).
grammar.formation: Verb stem + (으)면: If verb stem ends in vowel or ㄹ, add -면. If verb stem ends in consonant (except ㄹ), add -으면. Adjective stem + (으)면: Same rules as verbs. 이다 becomes 이면.
grammar.usageNotes: Used for general conditions, not for commands or requests. Often followed by expressions of result or consequence. Can be used for both present and future situations.

grammar.meaning: Want to (do something). Expresses desire or intention to perform an action. This pattern is used to express the speaker's wants or wishes regarding actions they want to take themselves. Cannot be used directly for other people's desires in declarative sentences.
grammar.formation: Verb stem + 고 싶다: Remove 다 from the verb and add 고 싶다. Conjugates like an adjective: 고 싶어요 (polite), 고 싶습니다 (formal), 고 싶어 (casual).
grammar.usageNotes: Only used for the speaker's own desires in statements. For other people, use 고 싶어하다 or ask questions. Cannot be used with adjectives, only action verbs.
